passage:
QS$$0 SHS$$ 	Passage 1
	The SHE$$ two-month-old baby has hardly roused himself from the long night of his first weeks in this world when he is confronted with some of the profound problems of the race. We invite him to study the nature of reality, to differentiate QE$$0 self and non-self, and to establish useful criteria in each of these categories.
	A project of such magnitude in academic research would require extensive laboratory equipment and personnel; to be fair about it,  it has taken just that to reconstruct the experiments of QS$$1 the infant. And there are few grown and fully accredited scientists who can equal the infant for zeal and energy in sorting out the raw data in this project. His equipment is limited to QE$$1 his sensory organs, his hands, his mouth, and a primitive memory apparatus.
	At two months, as we have seen, he recognizes an object that we know to be a human face and we know to be an object outside himself.
	But to the baby this is just an image, an image incidentally that he can’t differentiate from the mental image, the picture in memory.
	But this face is one piece in the jigsaw puzzle—a key piece, we think. Then gradually in the weeks to come the association of breast or bottle, of hands, voice, a multitude of pleasurable sense experiences begin to cluster around this face and to form the crude image of a  person.
		Meantime the infant is conducting a series of complicated experiments in sensory discrimination.
	We must remember that in the early months he does not discriminate between his body and other bodies. When he clutches the finger of his mother or his father he doesn’t see it as someone else’s finger and his behavior indicates that he treats it exactly the same as he does his own finger. It takes him some time, in fact, to recognize his own hand at sight and to acquire even a rudimentary feeling that this is part of his own body. In  the first group of experiments he discovers that the object that passes occasionally in front of his eyes (which we know to be his hand) is the same as the object with visual and taste qualities that he can identify. In another experimental series he discovers that the sensations that accompany the introduction of this object into his mouth are different from those experienced when he takes a nipple into his mouth, or a toy, or his mother’s or father’s finger.
	 Passage 2
	Very soon after SHS$$ birth, environmental SHE$$ forces, or response contingencies, begin to operate in conjunction with the infant’s  built-in response repertoire to produce learned changes in behavior. It will not be long before the baby, instead of awaiting a touch near the mouth to open it, will do so when the bottle or nipple is seen approaching it. Or the head may be turned in the appropriate direction when the baby is placed in the accustomed feeding posture.
	Such anticipatory gestures symbolize the QS$$6 essence of learning. Such response systems are the classically conditioned or Pavlovian variety, because they involve elicited behavior.
	Operant QE$$6 conditioning is in a sense also anticipatory; the infant makes a response presumably in anticipation of receiving a reward.
	Response consequences serve as reinforcers of the behavior, then, and tend to perpetuate the behavior. Thus an infant who spontaneously makes a sound, which is then followed by an attractive consequence such as sweet fluid or the smiling presence of the mother, will very likely repeat the act with increasing frequency as time (and reinforcement) goes on.
	Similarly, a response which is followed by an aversive consequence, such as a frightening noise, will tend not to be repeated in the future. The infant thus behaves in accordance with expectations about the availability of  positive reinforcers or punishments, based upon past experience.
	It must be clear by now that thought begins at birth. There are psychologists who would not want to term the anticipatory gestures just spoken of as thought. Even they, however, would have difficulty pinpointing the stage of development or learning at which the onset of thought occurs. It is perhaps more meaningful to speak of increasing levels of symbolization.
	A QS$$8 number of developmental theorists have postulated stages of QE$$8 thought development.
	While no two systems or theories of cognition or thought development are exactly the same, most are agreed that the baby begins with a primitive appreciation of what is there and what is not, and most agree that early in life what is not there is unimportant to the child.
	Only with increasing cortical development, cognitive complexity, and experience in sensing, perceiving, and storing information does the child begin to take into consideration the current absence of past stimulation and to  consider how things are different or might be different than they are. Such “mental manipulations” occur later and set the stage for very symbolic higher thought processes of which mature persons are capable.
header: The following passages concern the learning and behavior of infants during the first months of life. The first passage comes from a popular guide for new parents, the second from a textbook on child development.

questions.description: By stating that a two-month-old baby confronts “some of the profound problems of the race” (lines 1-5), the author means that the infant

options.description: will start to figure out what is real andwhat is imaginary
is far more intelligent that we may think
begins to understand that dreams are notreal
begins to locate his physical boundaries
soon learns to communicate with the world

questions.description: The author of  Passage 1 compares a baby with a scientist (lines 12-15) in order to make the point that

options.description: infants are tireless in their efforts to understand their environments
infants use a form of the scientific method
scientific experimentation is very timeconsuming
(D)an infant is a human laboratory
many scientific studies have been done on

questions.description: The author of  Passage 1 apparently believes that during infancy learning begins with

options.description: feeling loved
the baby’s senses
images that the infant sees
ideas stored in the infant’s memory
repetition of certain sights and sounds

questions.description: The account in  Passage 1 of how an infant learns to discriminate between has own body and the body of others suggests that

options.description: all babies follow one of several well-definedpatterns
the sequence is highly structured and precise
some babies learn more quickly than others
there are several different theories abouthow the process works
male babies learn differently from female

questions.description: According to  Passage 1, an important milestone in infant development apparently occurs when a baby learns

options.description: to grasp someone else’s finger with hishand
to remember objects like a mother’s faceeven when the object is out of sight
that his mother and father have differentfaces
that his own hand has a distinctive smelland taste
that his own hand is different from another

options.description: infants feel emotions just as adults do
every baby responds to the environment incertain predictable ways
every baby is born with certain instincts
infants naturally learn to respond to certainstimuli in the environment
healthy babies do not need to be taught to

questions.description: The author uses the phrase “classically conditioned” response system (lines 64-66) to mean that infants

options.description: use built-in response contingencies to satisfy their basic needs
cry when they are hungry
respond to their environments early in life
can be trained to learn from their environments

questions.description: With regard to an infant’s capacity to think, the author of  Passage 2 believes that

options.description: newborns are capable of thought
thought develops even without externalstimulation
real thought does not occur until an infanthas had some experience
the development of memory triggersthought
all newborns have the same thoughts

questions.description: The author suggests that the term “symbolization” (line 93) be used to refer to

options.description: fright that infants feel after hearing a loudnoise
vivid images in an infant’s mind
the difference between positive and negative reinforcement
a form of mental activity occurring in aninfant
an infant’s memory

questions.description: Passage 2 implies that one can determine the maturity of people’s thought processes by

options.description: observing their capacities to thinkabstractly
measuring the speeds at which their mindswork
checking their rates of intellectual growth
assessing the sizes of their memory banks
evaluating their abilities to retain

options.description: to manipulate ideas in a primitive form
to differentiate between things that are notthere and things that are
what to do when they feel discomfort
to distinguish between behaviors that provide pleasure and behaviors that don’t
to influence the immediate environment

questions.description: Compared to  Passage 1,  Passage 2 places more emphasis on the

options.description: research being done to understand newborn infants
parents’ role in helping an infant develop
external indications of an infant’s thoughtpatterns
emotional growth of infants
psychology of thought development

options.description: attention to theory
authority
